awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Selective Listening - Control for Connected Autonomous Vehicles in Data-Rich Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Two current trends promise to revolutionize the safety, reliability, and energy-efficiency of future
automotive transportation: (i) wireless connectivity of vehicles to each other, to smart infrastructure,
and to other mobile devices, and (ii) autonomy, ranging from driver assistance to full self-driving
autonomy. Connected autonomous vehicles (CAVs) are cyber-physical systems with increasingly complex
software algorithms in control of a physical vehicle moving in uncertain real-world environments.
Planned connectivity regulations and recent advances in vehicular autonomy by leading
manufacturers imply that CAVs will be ubiquitous in the near future. Roads will be data-rich
environments where a large number of wireless devices attached to vehicles, infrastructure, personal
electronics, and wearable gadgets will transmit multimodal data. In this scenario, two serious challenges 
arise for CAVs: (1) Onboard computational limitations may imply a de facto upper bound on the number
of data sources that can be accommodated by the autonomy algorithms, and may introduce the problem of
appropriately choosing a smaller subset of the available data, and 
(2) Given the finite amount of radio frequency
spectrum and the rapidly growing number of wireless applications and end-users, spectrum scarcity arises,
for which current communication protocols do not suffice. We observe that these two challenges are in fact
intricately related, and that it is beneficial to address them together.

To this end, the goal of this project is to investigate bidirectional interactions between the
technologies of autonomy and of wireless connectivity in cyber-physical systems. Using CAVs as
a case study in cyber-physical systems, we propose to investigate how estimation and control
algorithms affect - and are affected by - software-defined radio communications in spectrum-scarce,
data-rich environments. The technical premise of this project is an emphasis on data-rich environments,
where too much data can overwhelm autonomy algorithms, e.g. real-time short-horizon trajectory
planners for vehicles. The proposed approach of selecting the data sources that are likely to be
the "most informative" is a new aspect compared to planning algorithms in the literature.
Furthermore, this selection is dynamic, in that it evolves with the trajectory plan. This selective
connectivity also helps the wireless spectrum sensing algorithm to converge faster by limiting the
spatial regions to sweep for potential connections. The proposed trajectory planning algorithm is
based on the so-called method of lifted graphs, which promises to bridge the gap between fast
geometric path planning algorithms and slower control-theoretic techniques that incorporate vehicle
dynamical constraints. Beyond CAVs, the proposed technical approach can be applied to other cyber-physical
systems where several non-cooperative agents communicate over wireless channels. The proposed trajectory
planning approach is sufficiently general to allow the formulations and solutions of different
application-specific planning problems.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to investigate bidirectional interactions between the technologies of autonomy and of wireless connectivity in cyberphysical systems (CPS). Using connected autonomous vehicles (CAVs) as a case study in CPS, we investigated how estimation and control algorithms affect ? and are affected by ? software-defined radio communications in spectrum-scarce, data-rich environments, as illustrated in Fig. 1.

The research work in this project was conducted along two thrusts: (1) coupled sensor configuration and path-planning, and (2) modeling vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication link quality. The project outcomes include multiple peer-reviewed publications, mentoring of multiple graduate students, summer schools for outreach, and a mini-workshop.

Thrust 1 studied the optimal configuration of sensors in the context of acquiring data of most relevance to a path-planning problem. For CAVs, the most typical task is short-term path-planning to avoid collisions with other vehicles and pedestrians. This task is modeled as a problem of finding a path with minimum exposure to a threat, where "threat" is defined as a spatiotemporally-varying field indicating the possibility of collisions with other vehicles.  The threat field is a convenient way of merging information gathered from onboard sensors and from V2V communications. A method was developed to calculate this threat field and quantify its uncertainty based on noisy observations of nearby vehicles, and progress was made towards validating this method with a publicly available traffic dataset. Separately, a method was developed to configure sensors to observe this threat, with the objective of eventually merging these two methods. The sensor configuration method first studied sensor placement in locations of most relevance to the aforesaid minimum-exposure path. Next, this method studied configuration of location and field-of-view. This method was shown to provide near-minimum threat exposure path plans with significantly fewer observations as compared to state-of-the-art information-theoretic methods for sensor configurations. Therefore, this method was shown to be a promising way of reducing CAV onboard processing related to environment perception.

Thrust 2 studied the characterization of link quality, such as signal-to-noise ratio and bit error rate, for V2V communication links established by phased array antennae in the presence of various sources of external interference. Different road scenarios, such as an intersection and a roundabout are considered to determine the performance characteristics of the vehicle communication link. A method was developed for mitigating location errors in V2V links where digital beamforming is involved at transmitters and receivers, both.

The PI and Co-PI of this project co-organized three summer schools in 2016-18 with the objective of educational outreach to undergraduate- and graduate students, as well as creating an opportunity for CAV professionals to network with each other. All three day-long events were held on the campus of Worcester Polytechnic Institute and were attended by approximately 50 registrants each. Guest speakers were invited from academia and industry to discuss CAV state of the art. The PI and Co-PI also organized a mini-workshop, attended by about 55 registrants, at the NSF CPS PI meeting in 2019. This project supported, at various stages, three Ph.D.-level graduate students, one M.S.-level graduate student, and one undergraduate student.
